The subsequent growth of educational television stations,
production units and closed circuit installations created a new
set of problems, some of which are being referred to us for solution.
Thus, at our Allerton House Television Management Seminar in August
1957* the NAEB Television Operations and Development Committee
recommended that the Association expedite the activation of new
stations by stimulating local activity. Later the Educational
Television Project of the Southern Regional Educational Board made
a similar request. Proposals to accomplish this were among the
major items of business held over from the St. Louis to the Chicago
meeting. In order to make this session as representative as
possible With the limits of time and budget, the Board was joined in
Chicago by the secretary-elect (Haskell Boyter); the chairman and one
member from the permanent finance committee (William Harley and
Edward Rosenheim); one member from the committee set up by ETRC
affiliates to represent them to the Center (dames Robertson); NAEB*s
legal counsel (Leonard Marks); and the Executive Director
Associate Executive Director of NAEB (Harry J. Skomia and Harold Hill.)
One of the principal results of the Chicago meeting was a
resolution on educational station activation drawn up by a special
ad hoc committee (William Harley, chairman; Richard Hull, Leonard
Marks, Jack McBride, James Robertson and Robert Schenkkan) which
the Board unanimously adopted. Its preamble stated that the reserved
television channels might be lost if not activated; that the
